Mark Zuckerberg defends Peter Thiel's Trump ties in internal memo

0 unreads 47 comments

More fallout from the Facebook board member's $1.25 million donation to Trump

by Casey Newton @CaseyNewton Oct 19, 2016, 3:05p
  • share
  • tweet
  • Linkedin
  • pin

Peter Thiel's donation of $1.25 million to Donald Trump's presidential campaign continues to rattle Silicon Valley. A day after a nonprofit stopped working with startup incubator Y Combinator for keeping Thiel on as a part-time partner, Mark Zuckerberg defended Thiel's status as a Facebook board member in a message to employees. "We can't create a culture that says it cares about diversity and then excludes almost half the country because they back a political candidate," Zuckerberg wrote. "There are many reasons a person might support Trump that do not involve racism, sexism, xenophobia, or accepting sexual assault."

A screenshot of the memo was posted to Hacker News yesterday, and it later surfaced on Boing Boing. A Facebook spokesman confirmed the authenticity of the five-paragraph memo to The Verge. It appears to have been posted on Facebook for Work, the enterprise version of Facebook that the company recently made available to other companies.

Hacker News

Thiel has been a central figure in Silicon Valley since his days as a co-founder of PayPal. He later co-founded data analysis company Palantir and was one of the first outside investors in Facebook. His ties to Y Combinator, the valley's most successful startup incubator, have placed him close to some of the largest companies of the current generation.

Thiel's support for Trump has confounded an industry that has has been working to improve the gender and racial diversity of its workforce. Many of its most prominent CEOs are active in liberal causes and have donated to Hillary Clinton and other Democrats.

Thiel's endorsement of Trump has put those CEOs in a difficult position. On one hand he is a close adviser; on the other, his support for an erratic, racist demagogue has outraged many of their employees and partners. Like Y Combinator's Sam Altman before him, Zuckerberg defended the company's ties to Thiel by saying that the company has a moral obligation to consider a variety of viewpoints, no matter how abhorrent. "We care deeply about diversity," Zuckerberg wrote. "That's easy to do when it means standing up for ideas you agree with. It's a lot harder when it means standing up for the rights of people with different viewpoints to say what they care about. That's even more important."

Of course, as the designer Jason Putorti wrote on Medium this week, Thiel already has an outsized capacity to stand up for ideas he agrees with: he spent $1.25 million to promote them. Zuckerberg's memo reads as if he is defending Thiel's right to post on Facebook. In fact, the question is whether someone who promotes opposition to gender and racial equality should be allowed to serve as a steward for a company whose stated mission is to connect the world.

Tech CEOs "are being insensitive to is the fact that for many people, myself included, wrapping Donald Trump in the blanket of 'a major party nominee' is normalizing his behavior," Putorti wrote. "So because Mr. Trump is a major party nominee, normalizing rape culture and referring to it as 'locker room talk' is treated as normal political speech." He continued: "The lack of understanding of life experiences that, as privileged white men, they haven't had, reinforces one of the uglier stereotypes of Silicon Valley. Not taking a stronger stand allows this culture to continue to permeate this community."

Calls for Thiel to leave the board first appeared earlier this year, when at a time that Facebook's impartiality in serving as a conduit for news was being questioned, he and Hulk Hogan successfully sued Gawker out of existence. At the time it seemed clear that those calls would be renewed each time Thiel intervened in public affairs. Zuckerberg's memo may or may not quell employee dissatisfaction with the company's Thiel association  but it will remain a public-relations problem for the company as long as he's around.

  • Source: Hacker News
  • Via: Boing Boing, Gizmodo

Lack of prosecution does not mean lack of culpability. It can reflect lack of political will, lack of evidence, lack of winnability (conviction rates are a big deal for prosecuting attorneys), and a host of other factors.

FBI Director Comey said, without qualification, that others who had done the exact same thing as Secretary Clinton were not automatically exonerated, that the FBI and DOJ have pursued cases against the mishandling of classified material, but that they are electing not to do that now. The lack of Hillarys arrest and arraignment is a choice.

And the fact that you think it is an apolitical choice made in purely in light of brute fact is the height of ignorance.

DoctorCommunis

Thats still very much a sentence that could only survive at a major news outlet if its in an editorial piece. Reporting tries to steer away from judgments (even well founded ones) like this and state things from a detached, professional perspective
(i.e. Trump has been perceived and labelled as an erratic, racist demagogue by critics).

Moral judgments are almost always reported on rather than declared in journalism. Editorials are where news organizations let their moral voice come out, not on random little news pieces.

gohan19ken

For the past several years and even more recently, there have been an interesting debate online ideological censorship and progressive ideals within tech companies and conservative movements. For example, a few years ago, it was discovered that the CEO of Firefox donated $1k in support of prop 8, the cali voter approved law that banned gay marriage. And the internet got upset. Several sites restricted accessing of them from a Firefox browser. The CEO eventually resigned.

There have been a lot since then but today there is an interesting one with Peter Thiel. So, why is this interesting beyond internet grievances? On one hand, you can argue the liberals are being intolerance, they should support diversity of opinions, and that their actions are a form of censorship. Another argument is this is not about diversity, disagreement, or even censorship but about giving a platform to hate and normalizing such an expression.

And I honestly do not know what to pick because, personally, I want to support diversity of thoughts even if it is hateful but I do not want to passively give way to that hate. Because we saw this happen already in Europe during the 1940s and US in the 1960s.

And that is what is interesting to me, does freedom of speech and expression and value of diversity support stops at hate or does it includes it?

Posted on Oct 19, 2016 | 3:34 PM
ench

Freedom of expressing is such an interesting topic, and one we rarely discuss without massive baggage from other conversations. My response below does a poor job at directly answering your comment, but I felt like posting it anyways.

So often, individual events or arguments get rolled together into larger talking-points. People discuss "Liberals" and "Conservatives" as massive labels, when they do a very poor job of describing individual sentiment/politics.

For instance, "Liberalism" generally involved liberty, freedom for individuals, and is considered to be on the "left" of the political spectrum. Its also related to Libertarianism, which is usually considered "far right". Then theres socialism, progresivism, fiscal conservatism, nationalism, and so many others .

I consider myself a progressive and a democratic socialist. My views generally align with the "far-left". I am not however, liberal. I believe in big government and strong laws, laws that protect freedom of expression, but not freedom of power. I consider the two different. Im mentioning this here to try and be as clear as possible about my opinions and personal beliefs.

For a concrete example: Anyone can write that they support a candidate, they can opine all day long about the topic. I even support limited campaign donations, provided a level playing field. However, I do not support the rich and powerful exerting excessive influence through money. In my belief, Peter Thiel should not be allowed more concrete influence than myself, or any other average American. The same applies to Zuckerberg, or Gates, or any other rich human that is trying to influence politics, whether they agree with my views or not.

Freedom of speech, and freedom of expression do not by definition cover action (money). Peter Thiel took an action to support a racist man with apparent fascist tendencies. He is being attacked for his action here. Some people are undoubtedly also attacking his speech, but I see no hypocracy in calling for the removal of someone who took that action, while also calling for freedom of speech and expression.

This is another topic, but a very interesting read here. On hate speech and hate crime in law. The short version of my beliefs is, a person is legally entitled to be an asshole, or a racist, or what have you. They can hold any personal beliefs. Its the actions they take on those beliefs that are criminal.

As if it isnt already bad enough, this reveals the true future of our justice system yet another tool the rich and powerful can use to bend the country to their whims, just as lobbying has become for large corporate interests. Plutocracy. thats my real problem with Thiel. I could care less about his Trump donation to be honest. If he wants to throw his money in a dumpster fire, go ahead and let him.

jontseng

michiganjs, I think there are too questions:
1) Is it justified to allow someone who hold any political view (no matter how extreme) to hold a position of influence on the Facebook boy, on the basis that everyone is entitled to their opinion and personal beliefs should not affect what job you are allowed to do?
2) If the answer to question 1) is "no" then where do we draw the line between acceptable and unacceptable political beliefs for a Facebook board member.

I think the answer to 1) is no (you may disagree). The KKK example was a sort of though experiment. Without bringing in Godwins Law, maybe someone someone who expresses open support for the North American Man Boy Love Association would be another example (I assume it is perfectly legal to advocate for a change in the law to allow illegal acts to become legal ones). As I said you may disagree, but I think these examples give a strong prima fasciea case that there are some views that are beyond the pale.

Turning to question 2) this is where your example of Tim Cook falls down (as poopjuggler has pointed out). I dont think Tim Cooks views fall in the same category as Trumps open condoning of sexual assault, racial discrimination and imprisonment of political opponents.

I am actually more inclined to think that Palmer Luckey falls into this latter category also. Perhaps more stupid and naive than malicious, but to openly advocate and fund online abuse would be disqualifying behaviour for certain positions. Perhaps not for marketing dude at Oculus but I think likely for board member at Facebook.

Remember being on the FB board gives huge responsibility. Theoretically Zuckerberg and FB management are answerable to the board (board are answerable to shareholders ie Zuck but that is a separate governance issue). Given how much Facebook news feeds dominate political discourse I would hope such people are held to a higher standard.
